journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part I: Journal of Systems and Control Engineering

title-group.article-title: Slow–fast loop gain-scheduled switching attitude tracking control for a near-space hypersonic vehicle

article-meta.aff: 2College of Information and Control, Nanjing University of Information Science and Technology, China

author-notes.corresp: Changyin Sun, School of Automation, Southeast University, Nanjing 210096, China. Email: cysun@seu.edu.cn

article-meta.issue-title: Special issue on advanced control of aerospace vehicles

abstract.p: This article develops a slow–fast loop polytopic linear parameter-varying model and proposes a systematic gain-scheduled switching attitude tracking control scheme for a near-space hypersonic vehicle. First, the dynamics of near-space hypersonic vehicle is modeled as a slow–fast loop polytopic linear parameter-varying model using the Jacobian linearization and tensor-product model transformation approach. Open-loop simulation verification illustrates that the developed polytopic linear parameter-varying model captures the local nonlinearities of the original nonlinear system; therefore, it is suitable for model-based control. Second, for less conservative controller design purpose, the flight envelope is divided into smaller subregions, a family of slow loop and fast loop gain-scheduled controllers are designed, and each of them is suitable for a specific parameter subspace; the slow loop and fast loop gain-scheduled controllers are then switched in order to guarantee the closed-loop near-space hypersonic vehicle system to be asymptotically stable and satisfy a specified performance criteria. The resulting slow loop and fast loop gain-scheduled switching controllers are found by solving a convex constraint problem that can be efficiently solved using available linear matrix inequality techniques. Finally, numerical simulations have demonstrated the effectiveness of the proposed method.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Near space is defined as the atmospheric region from about 20–100 km above the Earth’s surface,1 it is a region that had historically been unused by aircraft due to the difficulty in generating lift in the low-density atmosphere at that altitude.2,3 Near-space hypersonic vehicles (NSHV) provide several possibilities that current technology cannot achieve, and they are being considered as a means of achieving both low Earth orbit (LEO) and reliable outer space access.4 It has even been suggested that the NSHV could be used in military and civilian applications because of high-speed overload and short operational preparation time.5,6 The problem of modeling for NSHV has drawn much attention in the past few years. A linear model for NSHV using the small deviation linearized method is developed,7 and the linearized model is obtained for the nonlinear hypersonic vehicle model at a specified trim condition, so that the linear controller can be designed in the neighborhood of the operating point. Actually, full simulation models for NSHV include intricate couplings between the engine and flight dynamics, along with complex interplay between flexible and rigid modes. Therefore, a flexible air-breathing NSHV model, which includes flexible dynamics, was developed in the study by Bolender and Doman.8 The dynamic of this model becomes exceedingly complex when flexibility effects are considered, so the model can be used only for simulations or validation purposes. In addition, the authors presented a control-oriented model of NSHV considering five rigid modes and four flexible modes in Parker et al.9 The new control-oriented model is derived by replacing complex force and moment functions with curve-fitted approximation and neglecting certain weak coupling and slower portions of the NSHV dynamics. Based on the control-oriented NSHV model, a quasi-linear parameter-varying (quasi-LPV) model is developed according to the first-principle model as described in Sigthorsson and Serrani.10 However, the quasi-LPV model is suitable for simulation and not useful for model-based control due to its complicated dynamics.4,11

On the other hand, the main challenge of the control law design for the NSHV is due to the high complexity of the equations of motion and the difficulty in measuring and estimating the aerodynamic parameters of the vehicle. In the past few years, some representative control techniques have been proposed for the longitudinal dynamic model of NSHV, such as robust linear control technique,12 nonlinear robust adaptive control,13–15 backstepping method,16,17 and nonlinear dynamic inversion method.18,19 Recently, gain-scheduled control has been widely used to deal with nonlinear time-varying systems, and its principle is to design local linear controller for parameter-dependent or nonlinear time-varying systems and then obtain the global controller using the interpolation approach.20–22 Based on D-K iteration, a robust gain-scheduling controller, which is scheduled on Mach number and altitude for NSHV, is presented in Lu et al.23 In addition, the authors design a gain-scheduled robust controller using the μ synthesis method in Yu et al.24 More specifically, an inner–outer loop gain-scheduled control structure is proposed to design the flight control system of NSHV, and an LPV antiwindup compensator is designed in order to enhance attitude stability and overcome actuator saturation in Ge and Huang.25 But, these studies have shown that standard gain-scheduled control for NSHV was conservative due to large flight envelope.26 Recently, numerous new results have been reported on switching control.27–29 Especially, based on a switched parameter-dependent Lyapunov function, switched linear systems with polytopic-type time-varying parametric uncertainties have been studied in Qiu et al.30,31

Motivated by the aforementioned reasons, this article is concerned with polytopic LPV modeling and gain-scheduled switching control for the NSHV. First, the NSHV is modeled as a slow–fast loop polytopic LPV model using the Jacobian linearization and tensor-product (TP) model transformation approach. For the large range of parameter varying, we divide the parameter region into small subregions and find a suitable Lyapunov function for each parameter subregion. Then, a family of slow and fast loop gain-scheduled controllers are designed, and each of them is suitable for a specific parameter subspace; the slow and fast loop gain-scheduled controllers are then switched. Finally, nonlinear simulation results show the excellent attitude tracking performance of the presented method.

The rest of the article is organized as follows: the ‘Slow–fast loop polytopic LPV modeling for the NSHV’, is presented, followed by ‘Verification of the NSHV slow–fast loop polytopic LPV model’. ‘Slow–fast loop gain-scheduled switching attitude control’ contains our main results. Simulation results are presented in ‘Numerical simulation’. The concluding remarks are then given. (See Appendix 1 for notation used throughout the article.)

sec.title: Verification of the NSHV slow–fast loop polytopic LPV model
sec.p: In this section, we will check whether the obtained slow–fast loop polytopic LPV model of the NSHV captures the local nonlinearities of the origin system. The command torque inputs lctrl, nctrl, and mctrl are defined as follows

Figures 1 and 2 show the open-system state responses of the developed slow–fast loop polytopic LPV model and nonlinear system; from these simulation results, it is observed that the LPV model follows the nonlinear model quite closely and we conclude that this model is suitable for model-based control.

caption.p: State responses of the slow loop polytopic LPV system and nonlinear system: (a) angle of attack, (b) angle of sideslip, and (c) bank angle.
State responses of the fast loop polytopic LPV system and nonlinear system: (a): roll rate, (b) pitch rate, and (c) yaw rate.

sec.title: Numerical simulation
sec.p: To illustrate the performances attainable with the proposed method, the numerical simulation comparisons are given in this section. In this article, the flight envelope covers Mach number Ma∈[6,24] and dynamic pressure q^∈[1400Pa,8800Pa]; it is divided into four subregions and Rq(q=1,…,4) is denoted as
and
Choose Π=I2 and
System parameters and the trimmed cruise condition of the nominal flight of the vehicle are set as follows

Multiple step signals of 0.09, 0.07, and 0.18 rad are used to generate angle of attack, sideslip angle, and bank angle commands, respectively. For the angle of attack tracking, the first step of 0.09rad starts from 0.15rad at t = 0 s, and after each 30 s, another step will be applied. Similarly, for sideslip angle and bank angle tracking, the first step of 0.07 and 0.18 rad start from 0 and 0.26 rad, respectively, at t = 0 s, and after each 30 s, another step will be applied. Meanwhile, these multiple step signals will pass through the following angle of attack, sideslip angle, and bank angle filters
where ςα=0.9, ςβ=0.8, and ςu=0.6 and wα=0.8rad/s, wβ=0.7rad/s, wu=0.5rad/s denote the corresponding damping ratio and natural frequency, respectively.
By solving LMI (37) and (50), Kfqj (q=1,…,4; j=1,…,4) are given as follows

Figure 3 shows the angle of attack, sideslip angle, and bank angle tracking performances. We can see that our method (dotted line) is better than standard gain-scheduled control method (dashed–dotted line) in keeping stable tracking of the reference trajectories. More specifically, the angle of attack, sideslip angle, and back angle tracking errors are shown in Figure 4; compared with standard gain-scheduled control method, a smaller tracking error neighborhood can be achieved using our method. Figure 5 shows roll rate, pitch rate, and yaw rate. It can be seen that they have satisfactory performances. Control torques lctrl, mctrl, and nctrl are shown in Figure 6.

caption.p: Comparison of tracking results (gain-scheduled control and gain-scheduled switching control): (a) angle of attack tracking response; (b) sideslip angle tracking response; and (c) bank angle tracking response.
Comparison of tracking errors (gain-scheduled control and gain-scheduled switching control): (a) angle of attack tracking error; (b) sideslip angle tracking error; and (c) bank angle tracking error.
Attitude angular velocity: (a) roll rate ; (b) pitch rate; and (c) yaw rate.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: This article deals with slow–fast loop polytopic LPV modeling and gain-schedule switching attitude tracking control problem of the NSHV. For controller design purposes, the NSHV is modeled as a slow–fast loop polytopic LPV model using Jacobian linearization and TP model transformation approach. It can be seen that the developed model captures the local nonlinearities of origin nonlinear system by open-loop simulation verification. Based on the developed polytopic LPV model, we present a novel gain-scheduled switching control scheme; in our method, the parameter polytopic region is divided into smaller subregions, a family of slow loop and fast loop gain-scheduled controllers are designed over different parameter subspaces. By switching characteristic function, the slow and fast loop gain-scheduled controllers are switched in order to guarantee the closed-loop system to be asymptotically stable and satisfy a specified performance criteria, the existed conditions of the desired switching controller are deduction by LMIs. Nonlinear simulation comparisons have validated the effectiveness and superiority of the proposed control method. Our future work will focus on designing a nonfragile gain-scheduled switching controller for the NSHV. Also, the existence of external disturbances may influence attitude tracking performance. Therefore, the methodology to improve the disturbance rejection performance is significant. Furthermore, fault-tolerant control (FTC) for the NSHV based on LPV techniques is another important problem in this field.
